repnme.cdata!:
Kyrgyz Republic - Energy Emergency
            Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Energy Emergency
            Assistance Project for Kyrgyz Republic were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was substantial, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and
            the Borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: procurement arrangements should also be
            tailored to the specific circumstances of emergency
            operations with considerable built-in flexibility. Project
            Preparation advance and advance procurement are some of the
            instruments to expedite procurement processes. Close
            coordination of donors and clear delineation of
            responsibilities is important in ensuring a comprehensive
            response from the donor community. It contributes to
            effective and timely response and lack of duplication of
            efforts. The specific responsibilities need to be assigned
            early in the process and need to be based on each
            institution's comparative advantage. Government
            commitment and an experienced and motivated counterpart are
            of paramount importance to ensure speedy preparation and
            timely implementation. Although emergency operations are not
            designed to address long-term policy issues, they serve as
            good entry points for a longer term engagement. As such, it
            will be prudent for emergency operations to be followed by a
            longer-term engagement, as was the case in this project.

14470285.admreg: Europe and Central Asia,Europe and Central Asia
14470285.theme: Infrastructure services for private sector development

repnme.cdata!:
Kyrgyz Republic - Energy Emergency
            Assistance Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Energy Emergency
            Assistance Project (EEAP) is to assist the Government of the
            Kyrgyz Republic to increase the volume and security of the
            energy supply, especially, the supply of thermal power in
            the winter season. The closing date for the project and
            Additional Financing (AF) will be extended from the current
            May 31, 2011 until March 31, 2012. The primary reason for
            the extension request is the significant delay in the
            effectiveness of the EEAP AF due to the change of the
            Government in April 2010 and the subsequent unrest in
            May-July 2010 that delayed implementation. Currently ten out
            of the total sixteen contracts under EEAP AF have been
            completed; four contracts have already been signed; and two
            more contracts are under process. The extension is necessary
            to (a) complete all the planned activities under the
            additional financing; and (b) process the final payments and
            carry acceptance of the works under the original project.

repnme.cdata!:
Kyrgyz Republic - Emergency Energy
            Assistance Project : additional financing

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Additional
            Financing for the Emergency Energy Assistance Project (EEAP)
            for Kyrgyz Republic is to increase the volume and
            reliability of the national energy supply, especially
            thermal power in the winter season, thereby supporting
            implementation of the Energy Emergency Mitigation Action
            Plan (EEMAP).The additional financing will help finance
            costs associated with the following: (i) a scale-up of
            project activities for the provision of equipment,
            materials, and spare parts to increase thermal power
            generation and heat output at the Bishkek combined heat and
            power plant for the 2009-10 winter; and (ii) corresponding
            scale up of the support for project management. No major
            change is anticipated in EEAP design, except that project
            indicators will be altered to include the scale up and the
            project closing date will be extended by a year until May
            31, 2011.
